11:06 am
PM

We’re straight to it this morning with the BoJ meeting outcome which
annoyingly only came through just as we would normally be going to print. So
here are our quick interpretations. The -0.10% policy rate has been left
unchanged as generally expected, however the breaking news is the
introduction of QQE with ‘yield curve control’. The BoJ has scrapped the
average maturity targeting for JGB’s and has stated that it will buy JGB’s so
‘10y yields remain around the current level’. The statement also includes the
passage that the ‘monetary base may fluctuate to achieve yield-curve control’
and that the BoJ is ‘committed to expanding the monetary base until CPI is
stable above 2%’.

PM

It’s early days and there is a lot of detail to sift through but these are the initial
headlines and the main takeaway to us is a tweaking of QQE rather than
outright further stimulus. We’ll have to wait and see what the full reaction is
from markets in terms of whether or not it’s seen as disappointing but the
price action so far has been supportive. The most interesting move so far has
come in JGB’s with the 10y yield up 7bps and a shade below 0% at -0.007%,
despite the statement talking about targeting 10y yields at the same level.
They briefly traded in positive territory for the first time since March. 2y yields
are 2bps higher and 30y yields are 4bps higher. The Yen is currently 0.60%
weaker at 102.33 but it’s been pretty volatile. The Nikkei and Topix are up
between 1% and 2%, led by the banks and insurers which are both up over 5%
no doubt relieved that there is no interest rate cut and a steeper curve so far.
The rest of Asia is firmer but gains are alot more modest. Gold (-0.30%) is the
only notable mover in the commodity complex. All eyes on Kuroda's press
conference at 7.30BST.

PM

So that’s one central bank (nearly) out the way but with one more to go today.
The Fed is up next with the outcome due at 7pm BST and the post statement
conference from Fed Chair Yellen to follow shortly after. A reminder that we’ll
also get the updated dot plots and the latest summary of economic projections.
With regards to the outcome, DB doesn’t expect the Fed to move this month, a
view also shared by the wider market however the key might be just how
hawkish the hold can sound. DB’s Peter Hooper expects the statement of risks
to be upgraded to ‘nearly balanced’ from ‘have diminished’ - which would be
a strong signal ahead of December - and that Yellen should indicate that there
was an active discussion of a rate hike this time, but that they decided to hold
for now because of mixed signals in both growth and inflation. Yellen will also
have to acknowledge that a rate hike by the end of the year is a reasonable
expectation if data comes in consistent with the committee’s expectations, but
she will probably also do her best to focus as little as possible on ‘December’
specifically. On that note, it’s likely that a substantial majority of the dots will
likely shift down to one 25bp rate hike this year (in June a significant majority
were projecting at least two hikes this year). What might be interesting is how
many remain above one hike this year and how many expect no hike at all.
Peter expects at least two in the former and zero to three in the latter.

11:14 am
BE

In this Ideas Engine, we explore how, in a number of developed
markets, it is getting increasingly difficult for the tobacco industry to
grow revenue and we consider why, in some cases, the profit pools
are shrinking. In several developed markets (that represent a significant
proportion of the tobacco industry's global profit pool) expenditure on
cigarettes is becoming an increasing proportion of a typical smoker's
discretionary income (15% plus) and demand is becoming more responsive
to incremental pricing (both in terms of volume decline and consumer
down-trading).

BE

We have concluded that, because of its geographical footprint,
Imperial faces a much more elastic demand curve than BAT. In
addition, we believe Imperial will continue to cede share as the value
segment, where it is currently over-represented, becomes more
competitive. We estimate this translates into a c500bps delta in the two
companies' respective medium/long term profit growth rates.

BE

With this perspective we have reassessed the relative attractiveness
of the two stocks and concluded that Imperial's PE discount is too
narrow. With Imperial facing a challenging near term outlook in its
important UK market and BAT starting to see an easing in the FX-related
pressure on its gross margin, we downgrade Imperial to Neutral (reducing
our target price to 4,000p from 4,250p) and re-iterate our Outperform rating
on BAT (increasing our target price to 5,200p from 5,050p).

11:15 am
BE

And you'll want the demand curve graphs. Because just look at them!

BE

11:15 am

11:16 am

11:18 am
BE

Anyway, here's the Imps working.

BE

A combination of a low take-out multiple, cheap debt and strengthening dollar
means we estimate the Lorillard acquisition will have added 23% to earnings
(and a similar increment in free cash flow) by the end of FY16. However
looking into FY17 the 'Lorillard story' will have largely run its course (with a
risk that Winston/Kool's momentum slows as the impact of the price reset
subsides) and we anticipate a significant headwind in the UK. The deepdiscount
segment's share of the market is growing rapidly (which is lowering
the average selling price) even before the 'sticker shock' of moving to packs
of 20 sticks and standardizing packaging (by May 2017). Disconcertingly,
although over-indexed in the deep discount segment Imperial is currently
losing market share.

BE

As we highlight in our report, a significant proportion of Imperial's profits are
in markets where the [retail] price elasticity of demand is approaching 1.0. In
addition, we anticipate PMI, BAT and JT will increasingly redeploy some of
their premium and mainstream brands into the value segment, where Imperial
is currently over-represented (with a still relatively fragmented brand
portfolio).

11:18 am
BE

Having assessed BAT and Imperial's relative attractiveness based on where
they sit on the demand curve, we have concluded that the medium term
profits growth differential is wider – at c500bps per annum – than Imperial's
current PE discount (to the BAT 'stub') warrants. We are lowering our price
target by 6% to 4,000p (from 4,250p) and downgrading our rating to Neutral
(from Outperform). Whilst recognizing Imperial's cash return attractions, we
no longer believe it will outperform the consumer staples sector.

BE

Oh, and I think Ben H noted yesterday that Japan Tobacco's in London. They come to London annually to meet investors, so it's very unlikely to mean anything.

11:33 am
PM

My word they are rather brave

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

PM

Majestic Wine has faced two issues in the first half of FY17E and while we are downgrading our estimates by c20%, we feel these issues are more short term in nature and do not reflect anything more sinister. A combination of a tough backdrop in commercial as well as a planned investment in Naked Wines USA not delivering intended returns are the two drivers. The core Majestic Retail business is on track and on target and Naked Wines in the UK and Australia is growing according to plan. We are disappointed to be cutting numbers, reflect this change in our new TP of 415p but remain of the view that the group's strategy and business is robust and should deliver long term shareholder value.

11:33 am
PM

Our new forecasts reflect a £4m decline in Fy17E profits with an equal downgrade in both the Commercial and Naked Wines business. The overall impact is shown in the table below. The impact on profits is much greater than that in sales due to a) a 200bps decline in Commercial GP%, 2) the investment in Direct Mail. Our sales forecasts are directly impacted by the quantifiable slow-down in commercial and a lower rate of new customers acquired in the USA.

PM

Strategy remains on track

Naked Wines reached an inflection point in FY16A in that the underlying profits generated from mature angels was now greater than the growth spend to acquire new customers. In other words, Naked Wines became self-financing of its own growth. We still view this as an inflection point and warrants a positive re-appraisal of the investment case. Test & learn, which has clearly not gone according to plan in the first half of this year, is all part of this process and is inherent in the culture of Naked Wines and most online disruptors.

It would be fair to say that it is unlikely that Direct Mail will be a favoured investment decision in the USA, in the future or at least not in a meaningful way. The group has a strong track record having favoured its more tried & tested plans of a) online marketing and b) tying up with partners. This philosophy has worked well over the years and while all indications leading up to this Direct Mail investment were positive, the nature of Direct Mail is inflexible requiring a capital commitment upfront with lower granularity on the underlying data.

There remains no issue with achieving scale investments with partners and there are a numbers of these plans well under way generating returns in line with and ahead of plans. Hence we do not see the disappointment of this Direct Mail campaign as anything but one poor investment decision.

We estimate that internally generated cash will be used broadly 1/3 each towards dividends, growth spend in Naked Wines and debt reduction. On this principle, the group still remains on track to meet all its medium term targets by FY19: (1) £500m of sales, (2) net debt / EBITDA of 0.5x in Fy18E and (3) the re-instatement of the dividend in FY17/18E.

PM

that's enough of that

11:34 am
BE

Yeah, just googling around, Naked Wines is aggressively voucher-y.

BE

Seem to remember the business was started by someone ex Virgin Wines, which is aggressively voucher-y.

BE

It's all just reinventing the Sunday Times Wine Club in a different wrapper, isn't it?

11:36 am
BE

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE

Whilst the core retail business and Naked in the UK and
Australia continue to perform well, the commercial silo and
Naked US have disappointed. There seem to be fundamental
problems at the former (although it is small in the grand scheme
of things) and we are minded to give management the benefit of
the doubt where the hiccough in the US is concerned. A direct
mail campaign simply did not gain the expected traction: it has
now been pulled but the P&L damage has been done. Forecasts
must come down and the shares will find the next few sessions
tough going, but the growth multiple should persist here and we
are moving our target price to 400p.

BE

Naked US: direct mail missed its target. Whilst the signs from initial trials
were encouraging, the direct mail campaign to recruit new Angels in the US fell
very flat when it went nationwide. It is not quite clear why things were so far
below expectations, maybe it was the need to finesse the campaign from
jurisdiction to jurisdiction, but either way the campaign has been pulled and the
focus returned to other recruitment styles. We would class the disappointment as
a one-off, but one-offs in the US do not come cheap and the P&L impact for this
year is £2m off EBIT (and a less severe downgrade to next year given lower
starting Angel numbers). There are few concerns in the UK or Australia, and we
have little doubt that Naked will crack the US in time, but today’s news is
disappointing.
Commercial: learning some hard truths. Since the Commercial side of the
business was separated from the Retail arm, it has been clear that as a standalone
silo it had challenges. It was very much supported (some would say propped up)
by Retail (which itself seems to be recovering strongly), and in recent trade a 200
basis point investment into gross margin has not fired up sales growth. There does
not seem to be an immediate plan to rectify the situation and it is another £2m
lost off the EBIT number. An internal review has commenced but it is unlikely
that Commercial will bounce back any time soon.

11:36 am
BE

Forecasts come back. The downgrade is straightforward: we have lost £2m off
each of the problem children’s EBIT and whilst the rest of the business is
performing well, there are no mitigating upgrades to ease the pain. So £16m of
PBT becomes £12m for this year and £23m becomes £20m next year. Each £1m
of PBT effectively represents 1p of EPS.
Naked still a very interesting growth vehicle. We remain very excited by the
prospects of Naked Wines and whilst the US issue is unfortunate, we would not
class it as careless or fundamental and see material growth from Naked over time.
The core Majestic Wine business is on an improving trend: the stores look much
better, as will be demonstrated by next Monday’s store visit. However, the
downgrades will doubtless deflate the shares and we are moving the target price
back to 400p.

BE

(@Forester: it used to be the bulk discount, which was the USP for functioning alcoholics with driving licences. Now, I dunno.)

BE

BE

Deutsche ..... well, Deutsche agrees pretty much. But it adds in a bit of price war stuff too.

BE

Tesco, which represents c.50% of the UK’s online grocery market has seen its
growth slow from 15% in H1 15/16 (Feb year end) to 9% in Q4 15/16 to an
estimated low single digit in Q1 16/17 and negative in Q2 16/17 – please see
Kantar data in Figure 1. This is due to an increase in the minimum basket size
from £25 to £40 and an increase in delivery fees. This is significantly more
material to Ocado’s near-term performance than the launch of Amazon Fresh
in London. That Ocado cannot deliver profit improvement in this environment
confirms our long held view about the challenge of profitably growing the
market with incrementally smaller baskets under the Ocado model.

11:43 am
PM

(Interesting backstory erlkin)

BE

Tesco’s new management is taking a more balanced approach to growth and
profit with regard to online grocery. As a result, the market has slowed from
15% in H1 ’15 to 7% in H1 ‘16. Ocado’s share of new online grocery sales
growth has increased from 10% in H1 ’15 to greater than 50% in H1 ‘16. Ocado is
benefiting from a less competitive Tesco but based on our Ocado profit
forecasts, the incremental basket is not profit enhancing, under either model.
While we recognize the difficult industry backdrop driving gross margin
pressure is outside of management’s control, we don’t expect this to change.

BE

10 EBIT margin, 9.0% WACC and 13x EV/EBITDA for our TV to arrive at our

Hollywood Bowl Group plc, the UK's largest ten-pin bowling operator, with a portfolio of 54 centres operating across the UK under the Hollywood Bowl, AMF and Bowlplex brands, is pleased to announce that 150,000,000 ordinary shares ("Ordinary Shares") have today been admitted to the premium listing segment of the Official List of the Financial Conduct Authority ("FCA") and to trading on the main market of the London Stock Exchange. Dealings will commence at 8.00 a.m. under the TIDM "BOWL" with an ISIN number of GB00BD0NVK62.

PM

Investec float

PM

The Company and its consolidated subsidiary undertakings (the "Group") is the UK's largest ten-pin bowling operator, with a portfolio of 54 centres operating across the UK under the Hollywood Bowl, AMF and Bowlplex brands. The Group specialises in operating large, high quality bowling centres, predominantly located in out of town multi-use leisure parks (typically co-located with cinema and casual dining sites) and large retail parks with all of the centres being occupied by the Group on a leasehold basis. The centres are designed to offer a complete family entertainment experience with each centre offering at least 16 bowling lanes, on-site dining, licensed bars, and state-of-the-art family games arcades.
